>From: "yurifromtomsk" <neuroevolution@...>

> > Here's a thought...  Why give connections a unique innovation number at 
>all?
> >   Why not assign their unique ID based on the innovation numbers of the
> > nodes they connect?  If you create a new connection between nodes 253 
>and
> > 275, then the ID for the connection could be "253:275".  Store the
> > connections in a hash table, and you have instant prevention of 
>duplicates.
> > Then, even if a connection is created 10 generations later, if it 
>connects
> > the same nodes, it's the same gene.  Even if the organism has 
>subsequently
> > gone off and formed its own species.
> >
> > Any reason why that wouldn't work?
>
>I think there is a problem to appear. You idea supposes some global pool 
>for connections information. Right? So there is no way to keep connections 
>that do link the same neurons but have different weights. It's just because 
>such connections are always the same for hash function as they have similar 
>IDs.

I originally thought of one hash per organism.  But now I think it would be 
one hash per node.  Too much work in C/C++, but very easy in Perl...

$network = {
  'id' => '1234',  # give each network a unique number out of the 
'innovation' pool
  'species' => 13, # same thing with species
  'fitness' => 0.121356,  # store the fitness value of this network, once it 
is known
  'node' => {
    'bias' => {
      'type' => 'input',
      'connections' => {}  # none
    },
    'one' => {
      'type' => 'input',
      'connections' => {}  # none
    },
    'two' => {
      'type' => 'input',
      'connections' => {}  # none
    },
    'output' => {
      'type' => 'output',
      'connections' => {  # weights are just made up...
        'bias' => 0.5,
        'one' => 0.5,
        'two' => 0.5,
        '65' => -1.0   # the one hidden node
      }
    }
    '65' => {  # ID is the unique innovation number
      'type' => 'hidden',
      'connections' => {
        'one' => 1,
        'two' => 1
      }
    }
  }
};

Makes building the directed graph extremely easy.  But it does presuppose 
something about how mutations and crossover take place...That a connection 
from a node with the same node/innovation ID to a node with the same 
node/innovation id, though they may not have the same weights, are a 
compatible structure, for the sake of speciation.  Do I understand 
correctly?
